title: The Terror Beneath

embed.description: Traders whisper stories of a beast below Shurima's sands. They say she stalks the caravans that dare cross her domain. They say she hunts those that run, and kills those that fight. But what if the stories aren't simple stories? What if they're true?

body:
We're going back to Shurima guys! Who knew it'd be so soon?!

So, a new champ's potentially on the horizon, I think she's a Brackern, others think she's Voidborn. What do you guys think?

> I would also like to point out this is the first time we are seeing Shurima natives that are not champions, ie. the civilian population. Also, Azir's restoration is ongoing, judging from the state of disrepair the palace(?) is in and the expansive desert.

The ornate building we see in the video is not in central Shurima. For clarity: there is Shurima, the city—the gleaming, palatial domain that Azir is residing in—and Shurima, the desert, which contains the remains of the rest of Azir's once-mighty realm.  Among the crumbling remains of the empire, we can see something incredibly dangerous has taken residence.

We want to include the "regular" inhabitants of Runeterra when it makes sense, to show just how special our Champions are in comparison to them and to give a better sense of what life is like in the world they inhabit.

Here's an example of a shock reveal that's absolutely fine, because **[it's introducing new material rather than retconning anything.](http://boards.na.leagueoflegends.com/en/c/story-art/1Bi3Xi6w-link-this-thread-next-time-narrative-makes-a-massive-change-with-no-prior-community-input)**

It's sort of sad that this is a cause for celebration, but: hooray! Narrative didn't obliterate a bunch of established lore!

Not only did Riot not wreck a bunch of its own lore, but this also means it creates less conflict with community lore. For example, a Void monster being discovered in Shurima fits (kind of eerily) well with the **[Hextech Revolution](http://leaguefactions.net/hextech-revolution/)** storyline from Factions, which is about the Void contaminating the Shuriman ruins. If they swooped in and said "actually, Shurima's been a thriving empire for the past few decades", that would have been an awkward retcon that would wreck Hextech Revolution and similar community lore, because it would diverge so wildly from the established lore that community material is built upon.

In other words, by restraining itself from another drastic retcon, Narrative is keeping things reverse-compatible.

> Here's an example of a shock reveal that's absolutely fine, because **[it's introducing new material rather than retconning anything.](http://boards.na.leagueoflegends.com/en/c/story-art/1Bi3Xi6w-link-this-thread-next-time-narrative-makes-a-massive-change-with-no-prior-community-input)**
> 
> It's sort of sad that this is a cause for celebration, but: hooray! Narrative didn't obliterate a bunch of established lore!
> 
> Heck, not only does she not wreck established Riot lore, but she seems to mesh quite nicely with community lore. For example, whether she's Voidborn or not, she'll still fit in great with the **[Hextech Revolution](http://leaguefactions.net/hextech-revolution/)** from Factions. (tl;dr: Void-contaminated sand beneath the Shuriman ruins is discovered, and proves to be an abundant and powerful hextech energy source, catalyzing the so-called "Hextech Revolution".)

It's nice that it coincides, but fan-lore shouldn't have an impact on official content.  That's like saying Star Wars fan-fiction should impact the movies and licensed books.

> It's nice that it coincides, but fan-lore shouldn't have an impact on official content.  That's like saying Star Wars fan-fiction should impact the movies and licensed books.

I was just so struck by how nicely it meshed that I had to say something.

It also goes to show how, when you don't demolish your universe every six months, it becomes easier for the community to tell stories set in that universe. Shurima's always been kind of scary and kind of "wild"; adding this Champion in meshes with that established setting, and thus tends to mesh with other lore which shares that foundation.

But I do partially disagree: I think that one major problem with Riot's violently "blank slate" approach is that it overturns years and years of community lore and immersion.

Again though, fan fiction (aka community lore) shouldn't have a place in official lore. I have to disagree with you there.  I understand the hyperbole when you said "demolish your universe every six months" because yes, it can get confusing and frustrating, but that's not what they did.  The retcon only took out the League, not the rest of the setting. Now, the characters are free and even "community lore" isn't constrained by the League anymore.  If that doesn't give everyone more creative freedom than before, I don't know what to tell you.  The league isn't a necessary Part of Runeterra and the city-states are still around; I don't see a problem with separating lore and gameplay in a moba.  

You could think of it like pre-retcon and post-retcon if you want. Just because the official lore no longer includes the League doesn't mean fan fiction can't include it.

> Now, the characters are free and even "community lore" isn't constrained by the League anymore. If that doesn't give everyone more creative freedom than before, I don't know what to tell you.

It doesn't work like that. "We deleted the Empire from Star Wars. Everyone has more creative freedom now!" I'm not going to waste an hour rehashing months and months of community discussion for you here. Read the Story and Art board and you'll find plenty of threads spelling it out.

As for the characters being "free", the lore community rejected the "Champions are slaves" thing a long time ago. Nobody's advocating for that. Riot used that as a strawman, and we're still quite bitter about it. Not only were we not made part of the discussion, but they didn't even fairly represent our opinions in absentia.

One thing we do agree on:

> You could think of it like pre-retcon and post-retcon if you want. Just because the official lore no longer includes the League doesn't mean fan fiction can't include it.

The lore community obviously will never convince Narrative to reconsider its "Great Retcon", or the misguided assumptions that led it there. I don't think that fight is worth fighting any longer. Instead, I believe we should direct our energy toward keeping community lore alive and driving it onward to better and better things. No more begging for table scraps from Narrative, no more pleading threads beseeching them to change their minds. I for one am done with that.

There is silver lining here: if Narrative isn't going to write about the League anymore, that means it can't screw it up. It belongs to the community now. We'll take much better care of it, and do much more interesting things with it, than Riot ever did.

And this rather brings me back to my original point, that so far most of Narrative's new stuff is pretty easy to bring into community lore. It'll always be weird when they abruptly retcon a Champion's backstory for the fifth time, but we've gotten used to that, and it certainly hasn't stopped us before.

>That's like saying Star Wars fan-fiction should impact the movies and licensed books.

Hmmm. Would that actually be any worse?

There are many reasons not to retcon everything every six months. One reason is that some measure of stability allows the community to get involved and participate in the story.

I can sit down right now and write a Star Wars story about, say, an ISB agent on Kashyyyk during the Galactic Civil War. I could have written the same story five or ten years ago. In all that time, there's been plenty of development and storytelling in the Star Wars universe, but they haven't executed any massive retcons that would compromise this sort of story. They haven't said "actually, there is no ISB anymore", nor have they declared that in fact the Empire is run by giant bugs called Troknar who eat Jedi.

If Star Wars were handled like Riot lore, the universe would be completely unrecognizable by now, and any community lore written since its founding would now be totally disconnected from the "canon" universe. (I'm setting aside the issue of Episodes VII, VIII, and IX.)

So far, the lore community has managed to adapt to recent changes: mostly by ignoring the Great Retcon and just incorporating new material into the traditional framework, that bizarre League of Legends universe that (**gasp!**) actually contains a League of Legends. If Riot continues along the path of the "Great Retcon" much further, though, I think the community lore and the canon lore are going to start diverging more seriously.
